d:chapter.d:title: Ratio
d:chapter.d:para: In his book Elements of Algebra, Euler says that anything we can increase or decrase is magnitude or quantity.

We will study ratios of quantities in this chapter. Many of you might already be knowing about ratios from earlier classes. A ratio is nothing but a comparison between two quantities of same kine. For example, 4 balls vs 7 balls or 12 shoes vs 8 shoes.
A ratio between two quantities Q1 and Q2 is written as Q1:Q2 most of the time. Q1 or the first term is called the antecedent and the Q2 or the second term is called the consequent.

To measure the ratio between two quantities typically we use fractions. A reduced fraction is tells us about one quanity being multiples of another or part of that. For example, 2 dozen bananas compared to 6 bananas can be written as 2∗126 or 4.

Ratios are abstract quantities because they are sheer numbers. In practice, considering our previous example we can say 2 dozen banans are four times 6 bananas. This four is an abstract quantity because it does not have a physical form.
Clearly, you can see that Q1Q1=mQ1mQ2 so the ratio does not change if numerator or antecedent and denominator or consequent are multiplied by the same quantity.

d:sect1.d:title: Comparing Two Ratios
d:sect1.d:para:
To compare two ratios we need to make their denominator same the we can deduce if they are equal or unequal. For example consider two ratios r1:r2 and r3:r4. Then, we can have
r1r2=r1r4r2r4 & r3r4=r3r2r2r4
Now since consequent is same for both the ratios we can determine which ratio is bigger or equal or smaller by determining if r1r4 is bigger or equal or smaller as compared to r2r3.

d:sect1.d:title: Ratio of Ratios
d:sect1.d:para:
Clearly, a ratio can be represented by a fraction of two integers. Now let us try to see what happens to ratio of two ratios.Consider two ratios: a:b and c:d. Thus we can write ratio of these two ratios as fraction
abcd or adbc
Therefore, we can conclude that it is eqauivalent to ad:bc.

When I said a ratio can be applied as a fraction of two integers then that applied to finite numbers. A surd like x is not a finite number because certain portion of its fractional part is not recurring. Therefore, when a surd if involved in a ratio cannot be represented as a fraction of two integers.
If we can represent a ratio exactly by two integers the quantities are called commensurable else they are called incommensurable.

d:sect1.d:title: Compounding Ratios
d:sect1.d:para: Ratios are compounded by multiplying ratios. The multiplication is done in simple fashion. Antecedents with antecedents and consequents with consequents.
For example, consider some ratios: a:b,c:d and e:f. The compounded ratio is abc:def.

d:sect1.d:title: Duplicate Ratios
d:sect1.d:para: When a ratio is compounded with itself once it is called duplicate ratio. If it is compounded twice, it is called triplicate ratio. If a square root is taken, it is called subduplicate ratio.

d:sect1.d:title: Antecedent vs Consequent
d:sect1.d:para: A ratio is of greater inequality, or less inequality or of equality depending on whether antecedent is greater or smaller or equal to the consequent.

d:chapter.d:sect1:
Common Properties of Ratios
A ratio of greater inequality is diminished and a ratio of less inequality is increased if we add same quantity to both of its terms. What is meant is no matter the ratio if you add a quantity to that then it will approach towards one if originally it is positive. You should be able to draw similar behavior for negative ratios and for subtraction as well. Say, we subtract a quantity from both of its terms then the ratio will move away from 1 on the number axis. Let us see how it works.
Let us consider a negative ratio. In that case, if we add a positive number to both its terms then ratio will move towards from -1 and if we subtract then it will move away from from -1.
Let ab be a ratio and we add x to both its terms so we have a+xb+x as our new ratio. Now,
ab - a+xb+x = ax-bxb(b+x)=x(a-b)b(b+x)
and aâˆ’b is positive or negative depending upon the fact whether a is greater or smaller than b. Hence, if
a>b, ab>a+xb+x
and if
a<b, ab<a+xb+x
Similarly, it can be proved that a ratio of greater inequality is icreased and a ratio of less inequality is decreased if we subtract same quanitty to both its terms. When two or more ratios are equal, we can denote that by a single symbol, which helps us in many ways. Let,
ab=cd=ef=...,
and
pan+qcn+ren+...pbn+qdn+rfn+...1n
Let,
ab=cd=ef=...=k;
then,
a=bk,c=dk,e=fk,...;
Hence,
pan=pbnkn, qcn=qdnkn, ren=rfnkn,...;
⇒pan+qbn+ren+...pbn+qdn+rfn+...=pbnkn+qdnkn+rfnkn+...pbn+qdn+rfn+...=kn
⇒pan+qbn+ren+...pbn+qdn+rfn+...1n=k
Similarly, we can say that when a a number of fractions are equal, each of them is equal to the sum of all the numerators divided by the sum of denominators,
⇒a+c+eb+d+f=bk+dk+fkb+d+f=k.
If, a1b1,a2b2,...,anbn be unequal fractions, of which denominators are all having the same sign, then the fraction
a1+a2+...+anb1+b2+..+bn
lies in magnitude between the greatest and least of them.
Let all the denominators are positive. Let, arbr be the least fraction, and denote it by k; then
arbr=k;∴ar=kbr;
a1b1=k;∴a1=kb1;
a2b2=k;∴a2=kb2;
and so on. ∴ by addition,
∴a1+a2+...+anb1+b2+...+bn>k;that is,>arbr Similarly, we may prove that
a1+a2+...+anb1+b2+...+bn>k;that is,<asbs
where, asbs is greatest of the given ratios.
If we have two equations containing three unknown variables in the first degree such as
a1x+b1y+c1z=0
a2x+b2y+c2z=0
Rewriting these we can have following;
a1xz+b1yz+c1=0,
a2xz+b2yz+c2=0,
Solving these we obtain,
xz=b1c2-b2c1a1b2-a2b1, yz=c1a2-c2a1a1b2-a2b1
So we can see that for x coefficients of y and z are used and for y, that of x and z are used and so on in a cyclic manner as given in image below:
Cross-multiplication of coefficients
Multiply the coefficients as indicated by the arrows. The ascending arrows are positive and descending ones are negative. This is called the Rule of Cross Multiplication.
Now expanding on previous discussion consider following set of three equations which includes 2.1 and 2.2 given earlier:
a3x+b3y+c3z=0
So by our previous rule of cross-multiplication between equation (2.1), (2.2) and (2.4) we have,
xz=b1c2−b2c1a1b2−a2b1, yz=c1a2−c2a1a1b2−a2b1
Now if we take these ratios to be equal to k then multiplying and substituting in equation (2.4) we have,
a3(b1c2-b1c2)+b3(c1a2-c2a1)+c3(a1b2-a2b1)=0
This particular relation is known as the eliminant of the given equations.

d:orderedlist.d:listitem: Find the ratio of ratios 4:7 and 11:5.
Find the ratio of ratios 13:24 and 34:23.

Find out that among the following pair of ratios which one is greater in the pair:
4:5 and 5:6,
34:33 and 68:67 and
124:63 and 233:120.

Find the duplicate, triplicate and subduplicate of following ratios:
2(x+3):y-5
a2+ab+b2:a3-b3
If x-2:3(x+7) has a ratio of 7:9 then find x.
Find two numbers in the ratio of 11:17 where one exceeds other by 126.
What number must be added to each of the terms of 5:13 to make it equal to 5:7?
What number must be subtracted from each of the terms of 33:37 to make it equal to 7:9?
If x-2:y-3=3:5, find the ratio of 9x-2y:4x+2y.

If
ab=cd=ef,
prove that
7a4b2+8a2c2-5e4f7b6+8b2f2-5e5=a4b4.

If ab=cd=ef, prove that ad is equal to
a5+b2c2+a3c2b4c+d4+b2cd2.

If
xq+r-p=yr+p-q=zp=q-r
prove that (q-r)x+(r-p)y+(p-q)z=0.

If
y+zpb+qc=z+xpc+qa=x+ypa+qb,
prove that
2(x+y+z)a+b+c=(b+c)x+(c+a)y+(a+b)zab+bc+ca.

If
xx=yb=zc,
prove that
x3+a3x2+a2+y3+b3y2+b2+z3+c3z2+c2=(x+y+z)3+(a+b+c)3(x+y+z)2+(a+b+c)2.

If
2y+2z-xa=2z+2x-yb=2x+2y-zc,
prove that
x2b+2c-a=y2c+2a-b=zqa+2b-c.

If
(a2+b2+c2)(x2+y2+z2)=(ax+by+cz)2
show that x:a = y:b = z:c.
If x=a-ba+b, y=b-cb+c, z=c-ac+a prove that (1+x)(1+y)(1+z)=(1-x)(1-y)(1-z).
If l(my+nz-lx)=m(nz+lx-my)=n(lx+my-nz), prove that y+z-xl=z+x-ym=x+y-zn
Show that the eliminant of ax+by+cz=0,cx+by+az=0,bx+ay+cz=0, is a3+b3+c3-3abc.
Eliminate x,y,z from the equations ax+hy+gz=0,hx+by+fz=0,gx+fy+cz=0.
If x=cy+bz,y=az+cx,z=bx+ay, prove that x21−a2=y21−b2=z21−c2.
If a(y+z)=x,b(z+x)=y,c(x+y)=z, prove that bc+ca+ab+2abc=1.
If la−b+mb−c+nc−a=0,la+b+mb+c+nc+a=0, show that l(a−b)(c−ab)=m(b−c)(a−bc)=n(c−a)(b−ac).

Solve the following equations:
ax+by+cz=0,bcx+cay+abz=0,xyz+abc(a3x+b3y+c3z)=0
ax+by+cz=a2x+b2y+c2z=0,x+y+z+(a−b)(b−c)(c−a)=0
If a(y+z)=x,b(z+x)=y,c(x+y)=z, prove that x2a(1−bc)=y2b(1−ca)=z2c(1−ab).
If ax+hy+gz=0,hx+by+fz=0,gx+fy+cz=0, prove that x2bc−f2=y2ca−g2=z2ab−h2 and and (bc−f2)(ca−g2)(ab−h2)=(gh−af)(fg−ch)(hf−bg).
